0.00.text:
Translator: Ellen Maloney
Reviewer: Denise RQ

7.72.text:
Hello, my name is Dave
and I am an anorexic.

13.83.text:
I have been recovering from anorexia
for the past eight or nine years;

22.52.text: That is what this is all about.

24.54.text:
Before we kick off, I am
very comfortable talking about this.

27.46.text:
I do not want anyone
to be awkward or kind of cringing.

32.08.text:
You can see me,
I am not butch or tough.

35.34.text:
I will be honest; I do not even
have a strong bladder.

39.88.text:
That is what this is for.
It is just a massive TENA pad.

46.62.text:
If you saw me in the street,
you are not going to think,

56.39.text:
You would be right because
I have been veggie for a while now.

61.03.text: There are certain things that I miss.

67.48.text:
There is a really good
reason that I bring it up.

70.13.text:
There are 1.6 million people in the UK
that suffer with eating disorders.

74.96.text:
Probably more, because a lot of people
feel embarrassed to talk about it.

80.08.text:
A lot of people do not realise
that they are suffering,

82.68.text: and that was exactly the same for me.

84.53.text:
A lot of my friends,
when I slipped into all of this,

87.06.text:
asked me how I was losing
so much weight so quickly,

89.79.text: and I guess I was embarrassed.

92.50.text: I used to tell them it was a combination

94.85.text:
of the Atkins diet,
coupled with being vegetarian.

104.75.text: By trade, I am a stand-up comic

108.18.text:
and I love the unique ability
that comedy has to reach people.

113.53.text:
I really wanted to use that
in order to help,

116.08.text:
and in order to change
how we see mental health.

119.88.text: It was a difficult show to write.

122.93.text:
It was a really tricky one
because I had to be funny,

125.67.text: but I had to be informative as well.

129.03.text: Obviously I wanted to be sensitive.

130.87.text: We did not always get the balance right.

133.30.text:
When we took it on tour
to the Leicester Comedy Festival,

136.04.text:
one of the first reviews said that the bit
I did on bulimia was too, "Gag-heavy".

144.55.text:
It is like saying a show on domestic
violence lacks punchlines.

151.14.text:
I want to promote change,
especially towards mental health,

153.98.text:
because we have not changed
our attitude in the UK to mental health

160.30.text:
Then we would have freak shows,
now we have reality TV.

164.28.text:
We just have not come that far,
and I wanted to use that.

168.13.text:
I will never forget the first time
that I ever tried this in a show.

172.38.text:
It was awkward. It was horrible,
it was awkward, everyone was really...

178.11.text:
After the show, a woman came up to me,
and she stood there, and she said,

182.46.text: "You were not really anorexic, were you?"

186.46.text:
I could not help but think,
"Are you calling me fat?"

192.41.text: I said, "It is all absolutely true."

194.26.text:
She just turned around,
and she walked off.

197.02.text:
I thought, "I have offended this woman,"
and that is the last thing I want to do.

203.04.text:
Then five minutes later, she came back,
and she stood there, and she said,

206.87.text:
"I can help you.
I can help you get over this."

211.15.text:
Then from behind her back,
she produced a packet of crisps.

216.49.text:
Like the answer to this neurological,
psychological, mental health disorder

222.42.text: was a packet of Monster Munch.

225.58.text: It was only then that I realised

227.54.text:
how little people
actually know about this.

230.39.text: So I decided to start telling my story.

233.62.text: For me, this all began when I was 17,

237.02.text:
and I had just got
the lead role in a play.

248.94.text: I am as surprised as you.

260.94.text: Some of my best friends enjoy musicals.

267.10.text:
I am a very left-wing person,
I am very liberal.

269.38.text:
The only thing I cannot
tolerate is gluten.

273.47.text:
I got this role in this play,
and I had to appear topless.

278.51.text:
I guess it was the first time that I have
ever had to think about my body.

282.76.text: I decided to lose a little bit of weight.

284.82.text:
I just did the usual thing;
cut out snacking.

287.01.text:
I just had three meals,
and I lost a bit of weight.

289.41.text:
Wanted to lose more,
so I cut out breakfast,

291.47.text:
just had two meals,
lost a bit of weight.

293.68.text: Wanted to lose a bit more,

294.92.text:
and then cut out breakfast
and dinner and just had tea,

299.34.text:
It was a great way to save
money on food bills.

302.09.text:
Although what I did lose in weight,
I also lost in Nectar points.

307.59.text: It is not all happy families.

310.16.text:
As I lost the weight, something
incredible happened,

313.08.text:
and I got noticed by this one amazing,
beautiful, wonderful, awesome girl.

320.54.text:
For legal reasons,
I am not going to name her.

322.95.text:
I am not going to get within 50 feet
of her after this goes online.

327.46.text:
All you need to know is she was amazing,
we started dating, and I fell in love.

335.65.text:
By which I mean, she was addictive,
exciting, and blooming expensive.

341.58.text:
But like heroine, she also became
a cause for me to lose weight;

345.34.text:
she became an inspiration to draw
me on, to lose more of my fat.

350.45.text:
Not that she ever made me. I really
want to get that across as well.

353.65.text:
She actually never actively
made me lost weight.

356.69.text: She hated that I was skinnier than her.

359.15.text: I will never forget one conversation.

360.99.text: "Does my bum look big in this"

368.56.text: You have to understand that in my mind,

370.45.text:
I correlated getting skinny
with getting this incredible girl.

373.39.text:
In my mind, I correlated getting skinny
with being good-looking,

378.27.text: I know that is mental now.

379.54.text:
I understand no girl has ever been asked,
"What do you look for in the ideal bloke?"

387.83.text: In my mind, that made sense.

389.38.text:
Inevitably when we broke up
and she broke my heart,

391.98.text: that was when it spiraled out of control.

394.44.text:
If we are talking about change,
one of the things that I want to change

397.87.text:
is that anorexia is not to do with vanity,
and it is very little to do with weight.

403.83.text:
It is about addiction,
obsession, and control.

407.20.text:
For example, I became absolutely
obsessed with exercising.

411.56.text:
Anytime I had eaten anything,
no matter how much,

413.99.text:
I would run upstairs to my room,
I would do 50 push-ups,

417.91.text:
I would do 50 sit-ups
and I would do 20 squats.

422.02.text:
It was then that my mum and dad
realised that something was up.

425.91.text:
They never approached me. They never
said anything to me about this.

430.58.text:
I did not know the reason
until I asked them recently.

434.19.text:
I said to my mum, "Why, when you knew
something was up with the exercise,

437.85.text: why didn't you say anything to me?"

440.32.text: She gave the most beautiful answer.

442.05.text:
She said, "Dave, when your teenage son
keeps on running up to his room,

447.36.text:
and all you can hear is rhythmical
banging, followed by repeated grunting,

453.52.text: you tend not to ask questions."

455.94.text:
I thought it was really sweet until my dad
put his hand on her shoulder and said,

459.81.text: "I thought you were a sex pest".

465.46.text:
"Sex pest". You never expected
those words at TEDx.

468.89.text:
Also, I became obsessed with weighing
myself, on a neurological level.

474.23.text: I started weighing myself in the morning,

476.28.text:
then I started weighing
myself in the evening,

478.54.text: to see how much my weight fluctuated.

480.36.text: Then mid-day to inspire me to eat less.

483.39.text: On average, about five times a day,

485.81.text:
I used to run upstairs, lock
my door, and weigh myself.

489.47.text:
Five times a day,
I used to lock myself away.

493.61.text: Dad thought I converted to Islam.

496.99.text: When he found out what was going on,

498.92.text:
he said, "Oh, I thought I was going
to have to buy you a Qur'an."

502.26.text:
I said, "Dad, we have been
over this. I am vegetarian.

509.13.text:
Side-note on that: when we did
The Birmingham Comedy Festival,

512.08.text:
a lovely Muslim fellow came
up to me after the show, and he said,

515.23.text:
"I really enjoyed the show,
it was absolutely lovely.

517.77.text: But you are a very weak person.

519.51.text:
Because what you call, "anorexia",
us Islamists just call Ramadan."

528.86.text:
I also became obsessed
with calories as well.

533.91.text:
To reduce calories,
I reduced portion sizes,

536.95.text:
so what I called, "Sunday lunch",
everyone else just called "tapas".

541.61.text:
It was weird for my mum
and dad at this point in time;

544.32.text: I am cheaper to feed than the cat was.

547.03.text: They did not know what to do.

548.75.text:
They went and sought help in the church,
they tried to drag me along.

552.60.text: I was going nowhere near that place.

555.58.text: Bread and wine? Talk about empty calories.

559.06.text:
I heard stories of miracles
and was entirely unimpressed.

564.13.text: That is plenty to go around, you know?

567.54.text:
Because I did not realise I had a problem,
until I ended up in hospital.

573.55.text:
I ended up in hospital
due to coffee-loading.

577.92.text:
Side-note on that: in case
you do not know what that is,

580.77.text:
"coffee-loading" is where
you substitute food for coffee.

584.70.text:
Coffee gives you all of the energy,
but none of the calories of food.

588.76.text:
Something you might not
realise about coffee

591.44.text:
is that coffee reduces
your pulse rate when you do not eat.

595.87.text:
Because you have got no fuel in your body,
that reduces your pulse too.

600.15.text: Mine got down to about 46 beats a minute.

606.15.text:
it is what is medically
known as 'heart block'.

609.01.text:
And unfortunately,
it is incompatible with life.

612.88.text:
I got rushed to the hospital,
and as I sat there,

616.77.text: I got talking to this building, builder.

630.65.text:
Do not worry. They will
fix that in the edit!

633.42.text:
Just to ruin it, I am going
to do it on this side now.

636.09.text:
The editor is going to have
a massive field day.

639.66.text:
Where were we? Serious point,
thank you very much.

642.85.text:
I was there, I was talking
to this builder, a lovely bloke.

647.84.text:
It turns out he was there because
he had circular sawed though his femur.

655.08.text:
After a while, we got talking,
and he said,

657.51.text:
"Anyway, enough about me,
what about you? Why are you here?"

662.86.text:
Let me tell you, nothing
is more embarrassing in life,

665.74.text: than when you look at a bloke

667.26.text:
who is bleeding through the lower
part of his body and you go,

670.31.text: "Why am I here? Oh, too much coffee!"

674.85.text:
You look like a bit of a 'word
that I am not allowed to say'.

682.38.text:
It affects people like Kelly Clarkson,
Lily Allen, Victoria Beckham.

688.45.text:
It is responsible
for a lot of rubbish music.

700.50.text:
I asked my housemate if he could
name any famous male anorexics,

710.55.text:
There is a gap in the market
for the first famous male anorexic.

714.99.text: It is not a very big gap.

719.51.text: That is not why I am doing this.

721.20.text:
I do not want fame or glory.
I am not doing it for that.

725.52.text: I do not want to be on television;

727.20.text:
the camera adds ten pounds,
you can go away.

731.48.text:
Men are much more likely to get bulimia
as well, that is something I meant to say.

736.07.text:
Only about 90% of anorexics
that we know of are female.

741.63.text:
Anywhere between 10% and 25%
are male, and that is on the increase.

746.74.text: Men are much more likely to get bulimia

749.12.text:
so there are a lot of famous
examples of male bulimics;

751.76.text: people like Elton John was bulimic.

754.89.text: So 'Rocket Man'? It is all about salad.

759.10.text: It is an incredibly big problem in the UK,

762.42.text:
and I know that because I am lucky
and honored to work with

766.72.text:
an incredible charity called, "Beat",
the UK's largest eating disorder charity.

770.49.text:
They gave me an award for the show
and the tour last year,

775.07.text:
I have a women there
that manages me called Rebecca,

778.01.text: and when we went to the Edinburgh Fringe,

779.96.text:
I realised as I got on the train, I needed
to send Rebecca at Beat an email.

783.69.text:
I pulled a pen out of my pocket and wrote
on the back of my hand, "Beat, Rebecca".

790.54.text:
You can imagine what the bloke
next to me thought.

793.38.text:
In his mind, "This is just some
really lazy domestic abuse."

797.89.text:
I was in a really cheeky mood so I just
looked at him and went, "She deserves it."

806.13.text:
Just before Christmas as well, I found
out, I am very lucky and honored,

809.73.text:
I am the ambassador of a charity
that helps promote the idea

812.65.text: that men get eating disorders too.

814.85.text:
They are absolutely wonderful,
I am now their media representative.

818.04.text:
I do all their TV, radio,
and press interviews.

820.79.text:
Also, subsequently, there is an interview
with me in a newspaper,

824.63.text:
I am not allowed to say which one,
but it rhymes with 'The Pluardian'.

830.79.text:
I did this interview with them
on male anorexia,

834.02.text:
something that I feel really strongly
and really seriously about.

837.33.text:
I did not realise that the media
have coined this phrase, "Manorexia".

843.42.text: It is just the worst word; "Manorexia."

845.84.text:
It sounds like the world's
worst superhero, right?

849.15.text:
Like, "Manorexia and Bulimia Boy
taking on the world,

854.38.text:
"Oh no, it is that evil nemesis,
it is Carbohydrate!"

863.16.text: He does not do anything, he just faints.

871.37.text: I am having a ball. What a lot of LOLs.

878.32.text:
Besides all the jokes, besides
all the mucking about,

882.21.text:
there is a really serious point
that I wanted to leave you with.

885.70.text:
That is that one in four anorexics
either tries to, or is successful at,

894.61.text:
It has the highest mortality rate
of any mental health disease.

900.21.text: People say to me now, "Are you over it?"

905.54.text:
I know this is something that I am going
to have for the rest of my life.

911.80.text:
But the real question
is, "Can I deal with it?"

915.35.text:
I can deal with it now,
because I can talk about it.

918.86.text:
I want to talk about it and show
that it is nothing to be ashamed of.

923.05.text:
I want to talk about it
so that we can help sufferers.

926.88.text:
And I want to talk about it so that we can
get that woman to realise that no,

931.69.text:
a packet of Monster Munch
is not how you get over anorexia.

938.15.text:
I just want to say it has been
an absolute pleasure to talk to you.
